snippet: Dmitri A. Medvedev’s transition from president to prime minister met more opposition than expected in Parliament, though it ultimately passed.
abstract: Russian Parliament, amid some dissent, confirms former Pres Dmitri A Medvedev as prime minister, completing a long-planned transition; one-third of Russia's parliament votes against Medvedev's accession, signaling his weakened political status. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW -- A day after stepping down as Russia's president, Dmitri A. Medvedev was confirmed as prime minister on Tuesday, completing a long-planned political transition that was nevertheless marred by unusual opposition to his candidacy in Russia's Parliament. Mr. Medvedev's accession to Russia's second-highest office was practically a foregone conclusion, given that Vladimir V. Putin, who was inaugurated to a third term as president on Monday, had promised him the post months ago in exchange for giving up the opportunity to continue his own presidential tenure.

headline.main: With Some Dissent, Russia's Parliament Confirms Medvedev
